docs.abstract: Quesillos - corn tortillas topped with a mozzarella-like cheese, fresh cream and pickled onions - proved to be a pretty tasty and very cheap Nicaraguan gem.
docs.lead_paragraph: The negative view of Central American cuisine is that it's like Mexican food without the spice. While there is some truth to that, I love Central American originals like pupusas from El Salvador (corn tortillas stuffed with pork, cheese, beans or a combination cooked inside, topped with pickled cabbage and tomato sauce), and baleadas from Honduras (wheat tortillas topped with beans, cream and cheese, then folded in half). So I maintained my optimism that there'd be a gem to find in Nicaragua as well.
docs.snippet: Quesillos - corn tortillas topped with a mozzarella-like cheese, fresh cream and pickled onions - proved to be a pretty tasty and very cheap Nicaraguan gem....

docs.abstract: Letter from San Francisco State Univ professor Sally A Scully disputes May 9 Arts & Ideas article on French and English cuisine (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Talk About a Fork in the Road'' (Arts & Ideas, May 9): French cuisine hardly sprang full-blown from the brow of Louis XIV. Rather, it originated in the Italian Renaissance, where the meal had become a work of art. When in 1534 the 14-year-old Catherine de' Medici left Florence for Paris to marry the future King of France, she and her entourage brought with them that Italian invention, cuisine.

docs.lead_paragraph: LAKE RONKONKAMA BY now most people are beginning to remove the Christmas decorations and giving thought to the inevitable stack of bills that follows the holidays. Not Carl Stroem. ''I like to keep the Christmas spirit going until March, until the spring,'' he said. On a recent snowy afternoon, as he sipped coffee and nibbled Swedish ginger cookies in the back of Scandia, his Scandinavian grocery and giftware shop in Lake Ronkonkama, he said that in his native Sweden the Christmas season ran from Dec. 13, St. Lucia's Day, until Jan. 20.

docs.abstract: Laura Shapiro essay traces the unlikely publication history of the cookbook Italian Food by Elizabeth David; notes that the book appeared in the United States in the 1950s, a time when few homemakers were even conscious that Italian cuisine existed.
docs.lead_paragraph: Elizabeth David’s “Italian Food” was ahead of its time, and not just because the food was unrecognizable to most Americans.
docs.snippet: Elizabeth David’s “Italian Food” was ahead of its time, and not just because the food was unrecognizable to most Americans....

docs.lead_paragraph: THE restaurant's name, Myrna's Mediterranean Bistro, suggests a grandiosity that belies the modest, tidy luncheonette on a busy street in downtown Stamford. What keeps Myrna's from being a clone of other places like it is the Middle Eastern menu. Considering there are so few Middle Eastern restaurants in Connecticut -- I can count them on one hand -- that alone makes Myrna's well worth a visit. While each Middle Eastern country has its own specialties, certain dishes are common -- hummus, tabbouleh, falafel and kebabs come to mind -- and some have been incorporated into the Western diet. These dishes are on the menu at Myrna's, along with other less familiar choices.
docs.snippet: The restaurant's name, Myrna's Mediterranean Bistro, suggests a grandiosity that belies the modest, tidy luncheonette on a busy street in downtown Stamford....

docs.abstract: Frank R Fioramonti letter comments on May 9 Arts & Ideas article on French and English cuisine (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your May 9 Arts & Ideas article on the history of French and English cuisine brought to mind a favorite aphorism that neatly summarizes the differences between the two: ''The only sure way to dine well in Britain is to eat breakfast three times a day!'' FRANK R. FIORAMONTI New York, May 11, 1998

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE of the most highly regarded new chefs in New York is Anne Rosenzweig of the East Side restaurant Arcadia. The 31-year-old Miss Rosenzweig has earned solid reviews for her distinctive cooking, whose style she describes as ''personal and, I hope, inventive.'' On a recent day she assembled a dazzling array from the menu of Arcadia, which is on East 62d Street: corncakes with gold and black caviar, creme fraiche and chives; a superb roast boned quail served in a ring of shredded Savoy cabbage with kasha nestled in the center; a salad with four lettuces, topped with YOUNG CHEFS rrxhRecipes are on page C6. fritters made with Gorgonzola cheese, and for dessert a chocolate bread pudding. A delectable, imaginativeseries, start to finish. Miss Rosenzweig's route to the 10- month-old restaurant, of which she is a co-owner, was a lively and adventurous one. She is an anthropologist who spent several years in Africa, India and Nepal. Touches of those faraway places frequently make their way into her dishes. ''In my travels I have always been influenced by techniques and flavors,'' she explained. ''I might use a spice that is common in Indian cooking - cardamom, for example - but the dish does not turn out to be a curry. I like to use a spice to give a dish a roundness, a distinction.''

docs.lead_paragraph: air markets. When Montse Guillen, one of the best cooks in the Catalan region, was in New York recently, Pierre Franey and I invited her to prepare some dishes for us. She arrived carrying a net bag containing a stone mortar and pestle, a terra cotta casserole and assorted essentials for her recipes, including a few giant heads of garlic, pine nuts and a jug of Spanish olive oil. She detailed a menu that, she assured us, would be quintessentially Catalan. The heart turned out to be a magnificent meat dish built around lamb chops and accompanied by escalibada, an elaborate yet easily made side dish of vegetables - eggplant, onions and green peppers -baked whole and served hot or cold and cut into strips. The food was served with four sauces, the most famous of which in the traditional sense is a romescu, a pungent, rich, nut and garlic sauce with a slightly biting flavor and the color of terra cotta. The others were garlic mayonnaises, each of a different character - one plain, one with honey and one with apples.
